titleStmt.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck, May 27, 1909
titleStmt.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
titleStmt.sponsor: Supported in part by a grant from the Wyoming Cultural Trust Fund, a program of the Department of State Parks and Cultural Resources.

distributor.name: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities

bibl.author: Cody, William Frederick, 1846-1917
bibl.title: Letter from William F. Cody to George T. Beck

msIdentifier.repository: University of Wyoming, American Heritage Center, Buffalo Bill: Letters to George T. Beck, 1895-1910 (Acc. #9972)

div1.note: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined With Pawnee Bill's Great Far East.
div1.p: I am feeling better thank you. I have gotten rid of the Bailey Estate.2 Lillie and I now own everything. 70 rail road cars. 170 big draft horses. Elephants cammelscamels in fact the Entire outfit valued at $300,000 of course it will take me a few weeks to pay some money I had to borrow. but six weeks good biz and I am clear. we will take $60,000 here this week. Lillie is a close conservative manager allwaysalways on the job. And it wontwon't be long now until I am on easy avenue again.
The last few years have been hard ones for me but I never weakened— and my good friends have stood by me. And I wontwon't for get them. And one of them is the First National of Cody.3

back.note: Note 1: Buffalo Bill's Wild West Combined with Pawnee Bill's Great Far East performed in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, May 24-29, 1909.
Note 2: James A. Bailey (1847-1906) died April 11, 1906, but his family retained financial interest in Buffalo Bill's Wild West until Cody and Gordon W. "Pawnee Bill" Lillie bought them out.
Note 3: First National of Cody was founded in 1901 by William F. Cody, Hubert H. Hake, Charles E. Hayden, J. W. Chapman, and Benjamin F. Hake.
